text: Projected total Primary Energy consumption for next year (2020).

name: Energy Types
text: There are fossil (f) and non-fossil (nf) energy carriers. Consumed energy consists of mostly fossil energy carriers.

name: Future Energies
text: Projected into the future (2100) the energy consumption more than doubles. This assumes no further climate policies. The shares of fossil and non-fossil energy carriers remain nearly the same.

name: Future Projections
text: Four other futures are possible. In every possible future the total energy consumption and shares of fossil and non-fossil energy carriers varies.

name: The Paris Agreement
text: The Paris Agreement’s climate target is to keep the increase in global average temperature to well below 2°C. In order to achieve these target it needs i.a. a shift in the mix of fossil and non-fossil carriers.

name: Our Current Path
text: In the possible “Middle of the Road” future, in which the climate target 2°C is achieved (through further climate policies), the share of fossil carriers is much lower and the share of non-fossil much higher than in the equivalent future without any further climate policies.

Fossil and non-fossil energy carreirs can be further subdiveded. This detail view visualizes the differences of energy volumes between a possible future (SSP 2) and its equivalent in which the climate goal 2°C is achieved.

Should a sustainable world (SSP 1) develop, climate targets can be achieved fairly easy. It would need only a modest carbon price to meet the 2°C target. The meeting of climate targets therefore requires less effort and might receive stronger support.
Let’s take a closer look at the energy carrier Oil and its development over the years. Even in a sustainable world (SSP 1), Oil will continue to be used extensively until 2050.
